column1:
A
nalysis of the posi(cid:415)ons of both par(cid:415)es

I
t  is  important  to  understand  the  overall  background  in  which  P2  and  P3  came  to  be
executed. The version of the Plain(cid:415)ﬀ that the 1st Defendant had a factoring arrangement
with LOLC Factors Limited since 2011 is borne out by P12 and the statement of account
rela(cid:415)ng thereto. The 1st Defendant did not deny that he had obtained factoring facili(cid:415)es
but  claimed  that  he  had  se(cid:425)led  such  facili(cid:415)es.  In  support  thereof,  the  1st  Defendant
produced a receipt issued by LOLC Factors Limited on 16th May 2012 for a sum of Rs. One
million [V1]. However, (a) as pointed out by the Plain(cid:415)ﬀ, V1 does not state that the said
funds  were  received  in  se(cid:425)lement  of  the  facility  made  available  by  P12,  and  (b)  the
statement of account P10 shows that the 1st Defendant engaged in transac(cid:415)ons in 2013
and  2014,  which  could  not  have  been  the  case  had  the  facility  been  se(cid:425)led  by  the  1st
Defendant.  The  High  Court  quite  rightly  rejected  the  posi(cid:415)on  taken  up  by  the  1st
